instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2015 13'' <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello, i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with corrosion on  <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> . I replaced the chip and the laptop worked great for a few days. Then it stopped working. Theres light on the charger but no fan spin, CPU gets hot. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>  are all present. CPU Vcore is 1.8v. 

When i resoldered <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to rule out a bad solder point, i noticed that when the board is still hot theres fan spin. After it cools out the fan wont spin anymore. I tried heating  <CHIP>U1600</CHIP> only with the iron but the fan didnt spin.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2015 13'' <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Probably is the CPU which reacts to heat.
Possibly accumulated crap underneath.

Check first all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
You may need to clean/remove J6100.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2015 13'' <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: On 4924 the fan won't spin unless the CPU is very hot.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 2015 13'' <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Thank you very much guys. Turns out the board was fine, I didn't know about the fan not turning on unless it was hot, so I thought it was not posting.
